verses.verse: It is better to have a dry crust to eat in peace than to feast in a house that is filled with strife.
A wise servant will rule over an unworthy son and will share the inheritance as one of the brothers.
The crucible is for silver and the furnace is for gold, but it is the LORD who tests the heart.
An evildoer listens eagerly to wicked lips, and a liar pays heed to a slanderous tongue.
Anyone who mocks the poor insults their Creator;[a] whoever gloats at anotherâ€™s distress will not go unpunished.
Grandchildren are the crown of the aged, and the glory of children is their parents.
Fine words are not becoming to a fool, and much less are false words to a noble.
A bribe is like a magic stone to one who offers it; wherever he turns, he meets with success.[b]
One who forgives a misdeed fosters friendship, but he who divulges it separates good friends.
A reproof makes a far greater impression upon a discerning person than a hundred blows will upon a fool.
A wicked man is only interested in fomenting rebellion; hence a cruel messenger will be sent against him.
It is better to come upon a bear robbed of her cubs rather than confronting a fool in his folly.
One who returns evil for good will forever have misfortune in his house.
To begin a quarrel is like unleashing a flood; so desist before the quarreling begins.
Absolving the wicked and condemning the innocent are both equally abominable to the LORD.
Of what advantage is money in the hands of a fool? Can he purchase wisdom if he has no desire to learn?
A true friend is one at all times, and a brother is born to render help in time of need.
A man without sense gives a pledge to become surety for a neighbor.[c]
One who sows discord enjoys strife, and one who constructs a high threshold invites disaster.
One whose heart is perverse will never prosper, and one whose tongue is evil will come to trouble.
The father of a fool endures endless sorrow and receives no joy from having begotten him.
A cheerful heart[d] is excellent medicine, but a crushed spirit dries up the bones.
A wicked man conceals a bribe[e] under his cloak to divert the course of justice.
A discerning man sets his face toward wisdom, but the eyes of a fool range to the ends of the earth.[f]
A foolish son causes grief to his father and brings sorrow to the mother who bore him.
It is not right to fine the innocent or to flog princes for their integrity.
One who uses words sparingly is truly wise; a man of discernment keeps his tongue under control.
Even a fool who keeps silent is considered wise; if he closes his lips, he is regarded as intelligent.
